column1: Historians agree that likely no soldier was named Orlando Reeves. Folklore is that Reeves was acting as a sentinel for a company of soldiers that had set up camp for the night on the banks of Sandy Beach Lake. Several different lakes are mentioned in the various versions

A memorial beside Lake Eola – originally placed by students of Orlando's Cherokee Junior School in 1939 and updated in 1990 – designates the spot where the city's supposed namesake fell.Conflicting legends exist. One legend has Reeves killed during an extended battle with the Seminoles after being field promoted after his platoon commander fell. An in-depth review of military records in the 1970s and 1980s
column7: turned up no record of Orlando Reeves ever existing. Some versions attempt to account for Reeves having no military records by using the name of other people named Orlando that exist in some written records – Orlando Acosta; however

column1: The geography of Orlando is mostly wetlands
column2: consisting of many lakes and swamps. The terrain is generally flat
column3: making the land fairly low and wet. The area is dotted with hundreds of lakes
column4: the largest of which is Lake Apopka. Central Florida's bedrock is mostly limestone and very porous; the Orlando area is susceptible to sinkholes. Probably the most famous incident involving a sinkhole happened in 1981 in Winter Park
column5: a city immediately north of downtown Orlando

column1: There are 115 neighborhoods within the city limits and many unincorporated communities. Orlando's city limits resemble a checkerboard
column2: with pockets of unincorporated Orange County surrounded by city limits. Such an arrangement results in some areas being served by both Orange County and the City of Orlando. This also explains Orlando's relatively low city population when compared to its metropolitan population. The city and county are working together in an effort to "round-out" the city limits with Orlando annexing portions of land already bordering the city limits.

column1: The Wheel at ICON Park Orlando
According to the Köppen climate classification
column2: Orlando has a humid subtropical climate like much of the deep Southern United States. The two basic seasons in Orlando are a hot and rainy season
column3: lasting from May until late September (roughly coinciding with the Atlantic hurricane season)
column4: and a warm and dry season from October through April. The area's warm and humid climate is caused primarily by its low elevation
column5: its position relatively close to the Tropic of Cancer
column6: and its location in the center of a peninsula. Many characteristics of its climate are a result of its proximity to the Gulf Stream
column7: which flows around the peninsula of Florida.

column1: During the height of Orlando's humid summer season
column2: high temperatures are typically in the lower to mid 90s °F (32–36 °C)
column3: while low temperatures rarely fall below the mid 70s °F (23–26 °C). The average window for such temperatures is April 19 – October 11. The area's humidity acts as a buffer
column4: usually preventing actual temperatures from exceeding 100 °F (38 °C)
column5: but also pushing the heat index to over 110 °F (43 °C). The city's highest recorded temperature is 103 °F (39 °C)
column7: 1921. During these months
column8: strong afternoon thunderstorms occur almost daily. These storms are caused by air masses from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean colliding over Central Florida. They are highlighted by spectacular lightning and can also bring heavy rain (sometimes several inches per hour) and powerful winds as well as rare damaging hail.During the winter
column9: humidity is much lower and temperatures are more moderate
column10: and can fluctuate more readily. The monthly daily average temperature in January is 60.2 °F (15.7 °C). Temperatures dip below the freezing mark on an average of only 2.4 nights per year
column11: and the lowest recorded temperature is 18 °F (−8 °C)
column12: set on December 28
column13: 1894. Because the winter season is dry and freezing temperatures usually occur only after cold fronts (and their accompanying precipitation) have passed
column14: snow is exceptionally rare. The only accumulation ever to occur in the city proper since record keeping began was in 1948
column15: although some accumulation occurred in surrounding areas in a snow event in January 1977. Flurries have also been observed in 1989
column17: and 2010.The average annual rainfall in Orlando is 50.6 inches (1
column19: a majority of which occurs in the period from June to September. October through May are Orlando's dry season. During this period (especially in its later months)
column20: often a wildfire hazard exists. During some years
column22: a strong El Niño caused an unusually wet January and February
column23: followed by drought throughout the spring and early summer
column24: causing a record wildfire season that created numerous air-quality alerts in Orlando and severely affected normal daily life
column25: including the postponement of that year's Pepsi 400 NASCAR race in nearby Daytona Beach.Orlando is a major population center and has a considerable hurricane risk
column26: although it is not as high as in South Florida's urban corridor or other coastal regions. Since the city is located 42 miles (68 km) inland from the Atlantic and 77 miles (124 km) inland from the Gulf of Mexico
column27: hurricanes usually weaken before arriving. Storm surges are not a concern since the region is 100 feet (30 m) above mean sea level. Despite its location
column28: the city does see strong hurricanes. During the notorious 2004 hurricane season
column29: Orlando was hit by three hurricanes that caused significant damage
column30: with Hurricane Charley the worst of these. The city also experienced widespread damage during Hurricane Donna in 1960.Tornadoes are not usually connected with the strong thunderstorms of the humid summer. They are more common during the infrequent cold days of winter
column31: as well as in passing hurricanes. The two worst major outbreaks in the area's history
column32: a 1998 outbreak that killed 42 people and a 2007 outbreak that killed 21

like other major cities
column3: experiences gridlock and traffic jams daily
column4: especially when commuting from the northern suburbs in Seminole County south to downtown and from the eastern suburbs of Orange County to Downtown. Heavy traffic is also common in the tourist district south of downtown. Rush hours (peak traffic hours) are usually weekday mornings (after 7 am) and afternoons (after 4 pm). There are various traffic advisory resources available for commuters including downloading the Tele-Traffic App (available for iPhone and Android)
column5: dialing 5-1-1 (a free automated traffic advisory system provided by the Florida Department of Transportation
column7: visiting the Florida 511 Web site
column8: listening to traffic reports on major radio stations
column9: and reading electronic traffic advisory displays (also called Variable-message signs
column10: information is also provided by FDOT) on the major highways and roadways.

column1: Interstate 4 is Orlando's primary interstate highway. Orlando is the second-largest city served by only one interstate
column2: surpassed only by Austin
column4: and is the largest metropolitan area in the US serviced by a single interstate. The interstate begins in Tampa
column5: Florida
column6: and travels northeast across the midsection of the state directly through Orlando
column7: ending in Daytona Beach. As a key connector to Orlando's suburbs
column8: downtown
column9: area attractions
column10: and both coasts
column11: I-4 commonly experiences heavy traffic and congestion. I-4 is also known as State Road 400.

column1: East-West Expressway (Toll 408) is a major east–west highway managed by the Central Florida Expressway Authority. The highway intersects with I-4 in Downtown Orlando
column2: providing a key artery for residents commuting from eastern and western suburbs including the University of Central Florida and Waterford Lakes area. The highway also intersects with the Central Florida Greeneway (Toll 417) and Florida's Turnpike. By late 2006
column3: the I-4/408 interchange had almost completed undergoing a major overhaul that creates multiple fly-over bridges and connectors to ease heavy traffic. The agency recently finished construction of lane expansions
column4: new toll plazas
column5: and sound barriers along the roadway

column1: Beachline Expressway (Toll 528) provides key access to the Orlando International Airport and serves as a gateway to the Atlantic coast

column1: Central Florida Greeneway (Toll 417) is a key highway for East Orlando
column2: the highway is also managed by the Central Florida Expressway Authority and serves as Orlando's eastern beltway. The highway intersects with the East-West Expressway (Toll 408)
column4: and begins and ends on Interstate 4.

column1: Daniel Webster Western Beltway (Toll 429) serves as Orlando's western beltway. It is managed jointly by the Florida Turnpike and the Central Florida Expressway Authority. The highway serves as a "back entrance" to Walt Disney World from Orlando's northwestern suburbs including Apopka via Florida's Turnpike.
John Land Apopka Expressway (Toll 414) A new east to west tollway serving northern Orlando. Phase I opened on February 14
column2: 2009 and extends from US 441 to State Road 429. Phase II will link SR 429 to US 441 several miles west of the current SR 429 intersection.

column1: Florida's Turnpike (Toll 91) is a major highway that connects northern Florida with Orlando and terminates in Miami.
The Orlando area is served by one through railroad. The line
column2: now known as the Central Florida Rail Corridor (CFRC)
column3: was previously known as the "A" line (formerly the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad's main line). The line was purchased from CSX Transportation by the State of Florida in 2013 and is now used by SunRail
column4: the Central Florida commuter rail system. Some freight spurs still exist off of the line
column5: which are operated by the Florida Central Railroad. Amtrak passenger service runs along CFRC. See also a map of these railroads.

column1: Amtrak intercity passenger rail service operates from the Orlando Amtrak Station south of downtown. The Mission Revival-style station has been in continuous use since 1927
column2: first for the Atlantic Coast Line
column3: then the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad (signage for which is still displayed over the station's main entrance). Amtrak's Silver Meteor and Silver Star service Orlando four times daily
column4: twice bound for points north to New York City and twice bound for points south to Miami. Orlando also serves as a transfer hub for Amtrak Thruway Motorcoach bus service. Orlando Station has the highest Amtrak ridership in the state
column5: with the exception of the Auto Train depot located in nearby Sanford.Historically
column6: Orlando's other major railroad stations have included:

column1: Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Orlando station (now Church Street Station
column2: a commercial development)

column1: Seaboard Air Line Railroad Orlando station (Central Avenue Station; 1898–1955.)

column2: federal and state funding was granted for the establishment of SunRail
column4: to operate on the former CSX "A" line tracks between DeLand and Poinciana
column5: passing through the downtown area and surrounding urban neighborhoods along the way. The service is expected to substantially reduce traffic congestion along the I-4 corridor
column6: especially between Downtown Orlando and the suburban communities in Seminole and Volusia Counties. Federal and state funds covered approximately 80% of the estimated $400 million cost for track modifications and construction of stations along the route. The counties involved approved local matching funds in 2007 and the line was originally projected to begin operations in 2011. However
column7: the project was ultimately voted down by Florida State Senate in 2008 and again in 2009 due to an amendment that would have approved a $200 million insurance policy for the system. Although there had been growing concern the system would be scrapped
column8: a deadline extension combined with a new insurance arrangement with CSX brought new hope that SunRail will be completed after all. In a special session in December 2009
column9: the Florida Legislature approved commuter rail for Florida
column10: which also enabled high-speed rail federal funding. SunRail began passenger service on May 1
column11: 2014. Phase I of the rail system runs from DeBary to Sand Lake Road in South Orlando. Phase II
column12: which isn't expected to be completed until 2018
column13: will connect from DeBary and continue north to DeLand
column14: as well as extend from Sand Lake Road in Orlando south to Poinciana. Attempts to establish a smaller light rail service for the Orlando area were also considered at one time
column15: but were also met with much resistance.

column3: President Barack Obama said that Florida would be receiving $1.25 billion to start the construction of a statewide high-speed rail system with Orlando as its central hub. The first stage would have connected Orlando and Tampa
column4: Florida and was expected to be completed by 2014. The second stage was to connect Orlando and Miami
column5: Florida. The project was canceled by Gov. Rick Scott in 2011
column8: the Florida Supreme Court unanimously turned down the request of two state senators to force Scott to accept federal funding for the project.

column1: A privately funded initiative known as All Aboard Florida

column4: the train currently runs from Fort Lauderdale to West Palm Beach with service to Miami Central expected to start in early May 2018. The Orlando extension will include 40 miles (64 km) of new railway track and terminate at the new Orlando International Airport Intermodal Terminal. Service to Orlando is slated to be launched in 2020.
